{"timestamp": "2026-02-28T16:38:03.729768+00:00", "source": "camelfinance.co.uk/lessons/using-the-replay-backtesting-price-action", "topic": "Camel Finance: Tradingview Guidebook - Using the Replay (Backtesting Price Action)", "findings": "Have you ever wished you could rewind the markets and see how you would react in real time? TradingView’s Bar Replay feature lets you do exactly that – replay historical price action as if it were unfolding live. This is excellent for practicing your swing trading eye and testing strategies on past data.

What is Bar Replay? Bar Replay allows you to simulate past market movements bar by bar. You choose a point in history, and then hit play – the chart will advance candle by candle at the speed you set . It’s like watching the market in a time machine. You won’t see future bars beyond your chosen point, so you can try identifying setups and making decisions, then see what the next candles bring.

How to Use Replay: First, note that Bar Replay is a paid feature (available on Pro/Plus/Premium plans) – free users won’t see the replay button. If you’re on a trial or subscription, you’ll find the Replay button on the top toolbar (it looks like a play icon ▶️). To start a replay:

Click the Bar Replay button. A red vertical line with a scissor icon will appear on your chart, along with a replay control bar.
Click on the chart at the date/time where you want to start replaying from . For example, you could click on a point last year right before a big move.
Once you select the point, the chart will jump to that moment in time (hiding everything to its right). Now use the controls: Play to auto-play candles, Forward to step one bar at a time, and a speed selector to adjust playback speed .
Watch the candles form as they did historically. You can pause anytime to analyze or draw on the chart (yes, you can use drawing tools during replay).
If you want to jump to another time, use “Go to…” on the replay bar and click a new start point .

Multi-Timeframe Replay: A powerful aspect – if you have multiple charts in a layout (premium feature), you can sync replay across all of them . For instance, replay both a daily and hourly chart together to see how they interact. In the replay control, you can choose to replay on one chart or all charts in the layout . “All charts” mode will align the starting point across timeframes, so you can monitor, say, the weekly and daily simultaneously as history unfolds – great for cycle analysis.

Practice Makes Perfect: Use replay to test your strategy. For example, you can pretend you’re trading in mid-2022: draw your trendlines and support, see if you’d have bought the dip, then hit play to see if it works out. It trains your pattern recognition without the bias of knowing the outcome. Perhaps you spot a head-and-shoulders pattern, place where you would short, and see if the market indeed falls afterwards.

Limitations: Keep in mind, not everything works in replay. Real-time elements like live news won’t show, and certain derived data (like some custom indicators) might behave differently without future data. Also, replay is bounded by how much historical data is available for that symbol/timeframe (e.g., you might not replay v", "domain": "trading", "tags": ["camel-finance", "cycle-trading", "web-content"], "quality_hint": "high"}

{"timestamp": "2026-02-28T16:38:03.730081+00:00", "source": "camelfinance.co.uk/lessons/2-trendlines-in-cycle-trading", "topic": "Camel Finance: Trendline Analysis - Trendlines in Cycle Trading", "findings": "In cycle trading, each market cycle (for example, a daily cycle or weekly cycle) has a series of peaks and troughs. Camel draws trendlines to connect these key points and to visually track the cycle’s progression. There are two primary types of trendlines used:

• Downtrend lines – drawn across descending swing highs during a declining phase. Breaking above a downtrend line often signals that a cycle low has formed and a new upswing is beginning.

• Uptrend lines – drawn under ascending swing lows during a rising phase. Breaking below an uptrend line can signal that a cycle peak (top) has formed or even that a cycle is failing.

Using Trendline Breakouts as Confirmation: Camel treats a trendline breakout as a critical confirmation signal. For example, when price trades and closes above a downtrend line, it confirms that the prior downtrend is over and a new cycle upswing is likely underway. This breakout serves as a green light to consider long entries, since it indicates a cycle bottom has been left behind. Conversely, if price falls and closes below an uptrend line that has supported the cycle’s rise, it warns that the cycle’s top may be in place or imminent, suggesting it’s time to tighten stops or take profit. By waiting for a candle close beyond the trendline (not just an intraday poke through it), false signals are reduced.

Camel’s strategy emphasizes combining trendline breaks with cycle timing. A trendline break that occurs around the expected timing for a cycle low or high is especially meaningful. For instance, if a daily cycle low is due and the price punches through a downtrend line, these two clues together strongly indicate the cycle low is confirmed. This alignment boosts confidence in taking a trade. Similarly, if an uptrend line breaks earlier than expected (an “early” top), it could mean a left-translated cycle (bearish scenario) is unfolding. In all cases, trendlines help Camel quickly validate what the cycle model is suggesting.

Avoiding Premature Entries: By relying on trendline confirmations (often alongside other signals like swing lows or moving average crosses), Camel avoids entering trades too early. A trendline breakout is tangible evidence of shifting momentum. This way, he sidesteps the risk of jumping in while a cycle is still headed down or getting out while a cycle still has room to run. Waiting for that clear break means a slightly later entry or exit, but with a higher probability of success. In summary, trendlines act as a safety check — ensuring a new cycle has truly begun or ended before fully committing to a position.", "domain": "trading", "tags": ["camel-finance", "cycle-trading", "web-content"], "quality_hint": "high"}

{"timestamp": "2026-02-28T16:38:03.730311+00:00", "source": "camelfinance.co.uk/lessons/3-yen-carry-trade-unwind-case-study", "topic": "Camel Finance: Trendline Analysis - Yen Carry Trade Unwind (Case Study)", "findings": "One notable real-world example of Camel’s trendline strategy in action was during a dramatic market event caused by a Yen carry trade unwind. In this scenario, global markets experienced a sharp, sudden sell-off triggered by investors unwinding massive yen-funded trades. This abrupt drop in prices initially made it appear as though an important cycle had topped and perhaps even failed (since the decline was so severe). Many traders feared that the bull trend was over.

What Actually Happened: Despite the panic, Camel’s analysis confirmed that the cycle did NOT fail. While the sell-off was steep, price never definitively closed below the prior cycle’s low on the timeframe being tracked. In other words, the essential criterion for a cycle failure (a lower low beneath the previous cycle trough) was not met.

The trendline drawn under the cycle’s rising lows was briefly breached intraday, but it did not see a sustained breakdown on a closing basis. Shortly after, the market stabilized and reversed back up, indicating the cycle’s top was not real. The sharp drop turned out to be a false breakdown or shake-out rather than a true cycle termination.

Camel’s trendline strategy allowed him and his followers to recognize that this was a temporary dislocation. The quick recovery back above the uptrend line and into the prior range was a strong signal that the cycle uptrend remained intact. This realization opened the door for re-entry into long positions at attractive prices once the dust settled.

Traders who had exited during the scare could confidently get back in when the market regained its footing, thanks to the trendline confirming the continuity of the cycle. The Yen carry trade unwind case reinforced an important lesson: stick to the defined signals and avoid emotional decisions.

Even amid unusual macro-driven volatility, the technical criteria (in this case, holding the cycle low and reclaiming the trendline) kept Camel on the right side of the market. By removing any implication that the cycle had failed, the guidebook underscores that one off event did not invalidate the broader trend.

Key Takeaway: A violent market move can test your trendlines and resolve, but if the market does not actually break the previous cycle low or maintain a breakdown, then the cycle is still in play. Traders should remain nimble – step aside during the shock if needed, but be ready to re-enter once price action confirms the cycle’s resilience. Camel’s approach in the Yen carry trade unwind exemplified trust in the technical signals over knee-jerk reactions.", "domain": "trading", "tags": ["camel-finance", "cycle-trading", "web-content"], "quality_hint": "high"}

{"timestamp": "2026-02-28T16:38:03.730561+00:00", "source": "camelfinance.co.uk/lessons/4-linear-vs-log-scale-charts", "topic": "Camel Finance: Trendline Analysis - Linear vs Log Scale Charts", "findings": "When charting and drawing trendlines, one must choose between a linear (arithmetic) scale and a logarithmic scale. Camel prefers to use regular linear scale charts for virtually all of his technical analysis. On a linear scale, equal vertical distances represent equal price changes (e.g. a move from 10 to 20 appears the same size as 50 to 60).

This straightforward scaling keeps trendlines and price patterns easy to interpret without adjustment. Camel finds that linear charts best reflect the actual price momentum and are more intuitive for setting levels and spotting breaks.

By contrast, logarithmic (log) scale charts space the vertical axis in percentage terms (so a move from 10 to 20, which is +100%, will occupy the same vertical space as 50 to 100, also +100%). Log scales are occasionally used for assets that have undergone enormous percentage changes – a common example is long-term cryptocurrency charts or very long-range stock charts – where price has increased or decreased by orders of magnitude.

In those special cases, log charts can make parabolic moves and long-term trendlines more visually manageable. Camel generally does not use log charts for his day-to-day trading, but he acknowledges there are niche situations (e.g. looking at Bitcoin’s entire 10-year history) where a log scale might be applied.

Impact on Trendlines: If you do switch between linear and log scales, be aware that your trendlines will often need redrawing. A trendline that is perfectly touching key highs on a linear chart may not line up on a log chart, and vice versa, because the scaling of price is different. For example, a straight line on linear scale becomes a curved line on a log scale chart (and thus is no longer a valid “line” connecting the same points).

Therefore, it’s important to choose one scale and draw trendlines on that scale for consistency. Since Camel sticks to linear scaling, all trendlines in his strategy are drawn and evaluated on linear charts. If a trader opts to use log scale for a particular analysis, they should redraw the trendlines on the log view to ensure accuracy of break points.

In summary, use linear scale by default for Camel’s strategy (simpler and preferred), and only consider log scale in rare cases – always redrawing trendlines after such a switch to maintain valid reference lines.", "domain": "trading", "tags": ["camel-finance", "cycle-trading", "web-content"], "quality_hint": "high"}

{"timestamp": "2026-02-28T16:38:03.731685+00:00", "source": "camelfinance.co.uk/lessons/5-camel-s-personal-trendline-drawing-rules", "topic": "Camel Finance: Trendline Analysis - Camel’s Personal Trendline Drawing Rules", "findings": "Camel has a set of personal rules and preferences for drawing effective trendlines. These ensure consistency and improve the reliability of trendline signals. When adding trendlines to your charts, consider the following guidelines:

• Use Wicks Over Closes: When drawing trendlines, connect the wick highs and lows (the extreme points of the candlesticks) rather than just the candle bodies or closing prices. By using the wicks, you capture the true extremes of price movement. Camel prefers wick-to-wick trendlines because they account for all intraday volatility, ensuring no significant price spike is ignored. This often means your line might cut through some candle bodies, but it will touch the furthest excursion of price.

📌 Note on Trendline Methodology

Traditional methods and the CMT curriculum often recommend drawing trendlines using the bodies of candles. However, Camel has found greater accuracy and trade precision using wicks instead. This variation reflects personal preference and real-world effectiveness over textbook theory.

• Minimum Two Touches: Ensure a trendline has at least two clear touchpoints before considering it valid. In practice, the first two points establish the line, and the third touch (or more) confirms its significance. A line drawn through only one point isn’t a trendline at all, and a line with just two points is still unproven until price interacts with it again. The more times price respects a trendline (touching it and bouncing off, or just undershooting/overshooting minimally), the more trust Camel places in that line.

• Preference for Shallower Slope: Recognize that steep trendlines are more likely to fail quickly. A very steep line (nearly vertical) indicates a sharp, aggressive move; while exciting, such moves often don’t sustain and their trendlines tend to break on the slightest pullback. In contrast, shallower trendlines (those angled more gently) tend to be stronger and more reliable. A gradual uptrend line, for example, implies a steady trend that can persist and is not overextended. Breakouts from shallower trendlines also have a higher probability of follow-through. In short, be cautious with steep lines; don’t be surprised if they break, and don’t bet the farm on them holding for long.", "domain": "trading", "tags": ["camel-finance", "cycle-trading", "web-content"], "quality_hint": "high"}

{"timestamp": "2026-02-28T16:38:03.732075+00:00", "source": "camelfinance.co.uk/lessons/further-trendline-case-studies", "topic": "Camel Finance: Trendline Analysis - Further Trendline Case Studies", "findings": "In this section, we take a deeper look at real market examples where trendlines have played a critical role in identifying market structure, potential tops and bottoms, and shifts in momentum. These annotated charts illustrate Camel\u2019s approach in action \u2014 from breakout sequences to failed retests, layered supports, and full trend reversals.\n\nEach case study highlights a specific scenario to reinforce the practical application of trendlines in live market conditions. Use these examples as a visual guide for refining your own charting techniques and sharpening your confidence when interpreting trend-based signals.", "domain": "trading", "tags": ["camel-finance", "cycle-trading", "web-content"], "quality_hint": "high"}

{"timestamp": "2026-02-28T16:38:03.732210+00:00", "source": "camelfinance.co.uk/lessons/introduction-to-camel-s-trendline-strategy", "topic": "Camel Finance: Trendline Analysis - Introduction to Camel’s Trendline Strategy", "findings": "Camel Finance’s trendline strategy is a core part of his cycle trading approach. Trendlines – straight lines drawn connecting successive highs or lows on a price chart – are used to quickly gauge market direction and identify potential turning points. In Camel’s methodology, trendlines are crucial for making informed trading decisions, acting as both guides to market trend and signals for entries or exits.

This guidebook outlines how Camel applies trendlines alongside cycle analysis, including special cases and personal drawing rules. The goal is to help traders understand how to draw reliable trendlines and use them to confirm cycle highs and lows with confidence.

📚 Reference Note

Much of the trendline strategy and methodology outlined in this guidebook is drawn from insights shared in this Camel Finance YouTube video:

This video provides visual walkthroughs and real-time chart examples of Camel’s unique angle-of-attack framework, including:

• How trendlines help identify turning points

• The logic behind multiple stacked trendlines

• The role of third angle violations in confirming tops

• How trendlines complement cycle analysis and timing bands

📌 For a deeper understanding and live demonstrations of these principles, we highly recommend watching the video as a companion to this guidebook.", "domain": "trading", "tags": ["camel-finance", "cycle-trading", "web-content"], "quality_hint": "high"}

{"timestamp": "2026-02-28T16:38:03.732298+00:00", "source": "camelfinance.co.uk/lessons/trendline-breakouts", "topic": "Camel Finance: Trendline Analysis - Understanding Breakout Types", "findings": "Not all breakouts are created equal. Recognizing the type of breakout can give traders a significant edge when planning entries, exits, and risk management. In Camel’s system, breakouts are categorized into four distinct types, each with its own behavior and implications.

This section breaks down the four primary breakout types — from clean, momentum-driven breakouts to deceptive fakeouts — and explains how to identify them in real-time. By understanding these patterns, traders can better anticipate market movements and respond with greater precision.

Let’s dive into each type and learn how to tell them apart on the chart.

To effectively illustrate the four breakout types in your guidebook, here are descriptions and suggestions for each:

1. Type 1 Breakout: No Retest

The price breaks through a significant support or resistance level and continues moving in the breakout direction without returning to the breakout level. This indicates strong momentum.

2. Type 2 Breakout: Retest and Resumption

After breaking through a support or resistance level, the price returns to test this level before resuming in the breakout direction. This retest confirms the validity of the breakout.

3. Type 3 Breakout: Hard Retest

The price breaks out, moves back below (in the case of an upward breakout) or above (in the case of a downward breakout) the breakout level, potentially triggering stop-loss orders, before resuming in the breakout direction.

4. Type 4 Breakout: Failed Breakout (Fakeout)

The price moves beyond a support or resistance level, suggesting a breakout, but then quickly reverses direction, trapping traders who acted on the initial breakout signal.", "domain": "trading", "tags": ["camel-finance", "cycle-trading", "web-content"], "quality_hint": "high"}

{"timestamp": "2026-02-28T16:38:03.732460+00:00", "source": "camelfinance.co.uk/lessons/bitcoin-btc-crypto-cycles-and-macro-confluence", "topic": "Camel Finance: Understanding Macro and Seasonal Cycles - Bitcoin (BTC): Crypto Cycles and Macro Confluence", "findings": "Key Macro & Seasonal Drivers: Bitcoin may be a digital asset, but it’s increasingly influenced by real-world macro currents and seasonal tendencies:

Monetary Policy & Risk Appetite: BTC has evolved into a “macro-sensitive” risk asset as institutional investors entered the space . Low interest rates and abundant liquidity have historically fueled crypto rallies (e.g. the 2020–2021 bull run amid global easy money), whereas tightening financial conditions can pressure Bitcoin as investors rotate away from risk. For instance, when macro fear spikes or stocks sell off, Bitcoin has often fallen alongside equities . It is not entirely an uncorrelated safe haven – in fact, its 30-day correlation with the S&P 500 has at times exceeded 0.7 (70%), indicating a strong link to equity market sentiment . Traders should monitor central bank policies (like Fed rate hikes/cuts) and overall risk-on vs. risk-off mood, as these set the backdrop for BTC’s cycle. Generally, looser monetary policy (rate cuts, QE) tends to create a positive macro cycle for Bitcoin by driving investment into higher-yielding or speculative assets. However the primary thesis of bitcoin is that it becomes a flight to safety and de-couples from equities, however this is still yet to be proven. It has shown recent strength (April-May 2025), and held up against a major SPX and NDQ selloffs and is starting to perform more and more like gold but this will be a long road and has barely started.
Inflation & “Digital Gold” Narrative: Bitcoin is sometimes dubbed “digital gold” and has been viewed by some investors as an inflation hedge. Notably, one analysis found Bitcoin had a high positive correlation with CPI inflation over the past decade . In periods of rising inflation or currency debasement fears, Bitcoin has attracted flows as an alternative store of value (e.g. during 2020’s stimulus surge, some sought BTC as protection against dollar inflation). However, this narrative competes with Bitcoin’s risk-asset behavior – in practice, severe inflation that causes aggressive rate hikes can still hurt BTC in the short run (due to the risk-off effect). Traders should weigh whether the market is treating BTC more like “tech stocks” or “digital gold” at any given time . Macro cues like real interest rates (inflation-adjusted yields) are informative: falling real yields (or negative real rates) tend to support hard assets including gold and Bitcoin, whereas sharply rising real yields (as the Fed fights inflation) can be a headwind.
Regulatory Tone & Institutional Flows: Being a nascent asset class, crypto is highly sensitive to regulatory developments. A supportive regulatory tone (for example, clear rules or approval of Bitcoin investment vehicles) can ignite multi-month uptrends, while crackdowns or bans have triggered sell-offs. ETF flows are a prime example – anticipation of a U.S. spot Bitcoin ETF in late 2023 fueled a powerful rally, with Bitcoin surging ~10% in a day to 18-month highs on speculat", "domain": "trading", "tags": ["camel-finance", "cycle-trading", "web-content"], "quality_hint": "high"}

{"timestamp": "2026-02-28T16:38:03.732946+00:00", "source": "camelfinance.co.uk/lessons/introduction-1747321962", "topic": "Camel Finance: Understanding Macro and Seasonal Cycles - Introduction", "findings": "Understanding how macro-fundamental and seasonal cycles influence asset prices can give traders a significant edge. Markets are not driven by technical patterns alone \u2013 broader forces like economic cycles, policy decisions, and recurring seasonal demand can create predictable tailwinds or headwinds for assets. By analyzing multi-timeframe trends (from month-to-month seasonality up to yearly or decadal macro cycles) alongside technical signals, traders can gauge the \u201cbig picture\u201d context behind price action. The goal is to identify confluence \u2013 for example, when a bullish technical setup aligns with a favorable macro cycle (e.g. an easing interest rate environment) and a strong seasonal period, the probability of success may increase. This concept is central to a Macro Cycle Confluence Score system, which assigns a score based on how many of these factors are aligned. In this guidebook section, we explain the major macro and seasonal cycle drivers for four key assets \u2013 Bitcoin (BTC), Gold, Crude Oil (USOIL), and S&P 500 (SPX) \u2013 and how traders can integrate these insights into a confluence scoring approach for multi-timeframe analysis.\n\nEach asset\u2019s section will cover: key macroeconomic factors and seasonal patterns, their historical impact on price cycles (with multi-month, annual, and long-term examples), and practical tips for traders on incorporating these inputs into a Macro Cycle Confluence Score or similar framework. By the end, you should have a clearer picture of why certain times of year or phases of the economic cycle tend to boost or depress each asset\u2019s price \u2013 and how to factor that knowledge into your trading strategy.", "domain": "trading", "tags": ["camel-finance", "cycle-trading", "web-content"], "quality_hint": "high"}

synthesis_content:
# Daily Synthesis - 2026-02-21 (Cycle 2 - Evening Update)

Generated by: zeke-reason.sh (Claude Code autonomous reasoning layer)
Feed entries analyzed: 193 total, 30 scored across 2 evaluation cycles
KG state: 75 entities, 59 relationships, 9 associations, 8 domains

---

## System Status: DEGRADED
ALL 8 overnight queue jobs failed with gateway timeouts this morning (12:56-14:17 UTC).
Gateway PID 95262 is running, Spark reachable at 10.0.0.143:11434. All quality entries
today came from the afternoon Reason cycle (Claude Opus), not the overnight Spark queue.

---

## 3 Key Strategic Insights

### 1. TLT PRIORITY: Position Breakeven Analysis at 4.85% 20-Year Yield

The 20-year yield at 4.85% (DGS20, 2/19/2026) puts TLT approximately at $87-89.
Using TLT effective duration of ~17 years:

| Position | Strike | Qty  | Approx Breakeven TLT | Required Yield Drop | Probability |
|----------|--------|------|----------------------|---------------------|-------------|
| $90C     | $90    | 650  | ~$93-95 at expiry    | ~55-85bps to 4.0%   | Moderate    |
| $95C     | $95    | 300  | ~$98-100 at expiry   | ~85-105bps to 3.8%  | Low-Mod     |
| $101C    | $101   | 3150 | ~$104-107 at expiry  | ~115bps to 3.7%     | Low         |
| Shares   | -      | 1868 | At cost basis        | Any decline          | Moderate    |

Duration math: 17yr × 0.85% yield drop = ~14.5% price increase → TLT $87 × 1.145 = ~$100.
So a move from 4.85% to 4.0% gets TLT to ~$100 — making $90C and $95C profitable, but
$101C marginal. The $101C (3150 contracts) needs a recession-level catalyst.

Macro signals this week:
- Fed minutes: hawkish pause confirmed (bearish near-term for bonds)
- Jan jobs: 130k (below 150k trend — mildly supportive)
- 10-year: 4.1% (stable, not breaking lower)
- RIKB auction data captured was ICELANDIC bonds (search error) — US data still needed
- MOVE index level: NOT YET CAPTURED — critical gap

TLT VERDICT: No immediate catalyst for the ~115bps rally $101C needs. The $90C position
is more realistic. Watch: March FOMC (3/19), Q1 GDP, credit spread widening. Time decay
accelerating — 11 months to 1/15/27 expiry.

### 2. Longevity Research Hit Peak Productivity — 4 Score-5 Entries

The afternoon Reason cycle produced the best research day since tracking began:

a) p-tau217 commercial availability: 8 labs now offering testing (Labcorp test code
   484390, Mayo PT217, Lucent, Genova, TrueHealthLabs, ALZpath, C2N, Quest). Cost
   $195-$400. FDA cleared Lumipulse G pTau217/AB42 ratio May 2025. Insurance coverage
   expanding. ACTIONABLE: Matt should consider testing given 3-4 year prediction window.

b) AKL003 Phase 1b: Launched 2/19/2026 (2 days ago), actively recruiting ages 25-75.
   Alpha Klotho mRNA in LNPs, IV administration, 2:1 randomization, single site at GARM
   Clinic in Prospera, Roatan, Honduras. NOT on ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT07216781 unclear).

c) DMTF1: Science Advances Jan 2026 (DOI: 10.1126/sciadv.ady5905). DMTF1 upregulation
   rescues aged neural
priorities_content:
# Research Priorities — Updated 2026-02-27

## High Priority
1. **Rapamycin / Longevity Protocol** — PEARL trial confirmed 10mg weekly safe for 48wk.
   Research: optimal dosing windows, combination with other interventions (metformin, NMN).
2. **Treasury Yield Watch** — 10yr at ~3.99%. Research: historical TLT behavior at 4% threshold,
   Fed trajectory signals, duration risk in current macro.
3. **AI Agent Capability Gaps** — SWE-Bench Pro at ~23% vs Verified at 70%+.
   Research: what task classes remain hard; which agent architectures close the gap.

## Medium Priority
4. **Tool-Calling Reliability** — BFCL top models at 80%+ multi-step.
   Research: failure modes, schema design patterns that improve success rates.
5. **Feed Quality / Dedup** — High repetition detected in self-improvement and synthesis topics.
   Action: implement dedup hash-check before appending to learning-feed.jsonl.

## Low Priority / Monitor
6. **Spaced Repetition** — Well-established; no new research needed unless novel protocol emerges.
7. **Compound Synthesis entries** — Many are restatements; lower research value until new data arrives.

## Retired / Saturated
- None this cycle.

strategic_context:
# Claude Strategic Context — Zeke Ecosystem

Last updated: 2026-02-21T15:30:00Z
Purpose: Claude's extended memory. Captures decisions, mistakes, principles, and Matt's patterns so every conversation starts informed.

## Matt's Core Values
- Never ask questions with obvious answers — make the safe/obvious choice automatically
- Anticipate 2 steps ahead. If something will be needed, build it now
- One complete paste block per task. Never split. Never ask "should I?"
- Operational requirements BEFORE features (permissions, monitoring, error handling, self-healing)
- Longitudinal data over snapshots — show progression over time
- Push shareworthy things to Telegram automatically. Never push routine status.
- Be concise. Don't describe what you built — let output speak.
- Matt is a strategist, not an engineer. Minimize cognitive load.
- Never touch running processes. If pipeline is active, only modify dashboard/monitoring.
- When presenting options, choose the safe default. Only ask if genuinely ambiguous.

## What's Actually Deployed (verify via endpoints, don't trust static numbers)
- Pipeline: ~/zeke-queue.sh (GATHER x6 → EXTRACT → ASSOCIATE, 900s timeout per job)
- Reasoning: ~/zeke-reason.sh (Claude Code Opus, 9 tasks including self-heal + ops-status)
- Dashboard: ~/zeke-dashboard-server.py port 3333, ~/zeke-dashboard.html, launchd plist
- Status bridge: ~/zeke-status/build-status.py + history.jsonl, GitHub push every 10min
- Cloudflare tunnel: running but EPHEMERAL — dies on reboot, URL changes. Needs launchd plist.
- Crontab: 11pm queue, 7am reasoning, every 10min status push
- 29 old Sonnet cron jobs still active — don't disable until 2 successful autonomous cycles
- byProvider: spark/qwen3-32b-32k has 6 tools (exec, read, write, web_search, memory_search, web_fetch). Memory says remove write but verify actual openclaw.json before changing.
- Claude Code permissions: ~/.claude/settings.json allows all, --dangerously-skip-permissions in headless scripts

## Decision History (with rationale)
- Local models limited to 6 tools — param mangling above ~6
- Local models overwrite files — use exec with >> append only (write tool removal TBD verify)
- delivery.mode "none" not "announce" — announce without targets causes system failures
- 900s timeout up from 600s — treasury-bonds succeeds at 893s
- Self-improvement prompt rewritten to specific terms after 6 consecutive dry runs
- Timestamp TIMESTAMP literals replaced with natural language instruction in 12 job prompts
- GitHub status bridge chosen over Gist — raw.githubusercontent.com has 3-5min CDN cache
- Sequential pipeline, not parallel — Spark loads one model at a time efficiently
- Hybrid arch: Spark ($0) GATHER/EXTRACT/ASSOCIATE, Claude Code CLI ($0 on Max sub) REASON/SELF-HEAL
- KG uses SQLite + nomic-embed-text, 0.92 cosine similarity dedup threshold

## Mistakes Made (principles extracted)
- STATELESS: Claude Code has zero memory between sessions. Every prompt must read existing files first,
